div.p: THE PRINCESSE: OR, Love at first Sight. A TRAGI-COMEDY: The Scene NAPLES and SICILY.
Written in Naples BY THOMAS KILLIGREW.
Dedicated to his dear Niece THE LADY ANNE WENTWORTH, WIFE TO The LORD LOVELACE.
LONDON: Printed by J. Macock, for Henry Herringman; and are to be sold at his Shop at the sign of the Blew-Anchor, in the lower Walk of the New Exchange. 1663.

div.head: THE Scene in SICILY and NAPLES.

list.head: Dramatis Personae.
list.item: FAcertes, late Prince, now King of Sicily (by his Fathers late death in Battel) taken Prisoner by the Romans.
Lucius, (under the name of Cilius) Brother to Facertes.
Bragadine, Son to the Governour of Naples.
Terresius, a Sicilian Commander, turn'd Pirate.
Tullius, an humorous Companion of theirs.
Pimp and Baud of Naples (Baud's name Olympia.)
Cicilia, Sister to Facertes and Lucius.

div.head: THE PRINCESSE: OR, Love at first Sight.
ACT. I. SCEN. I.
div.stage: Enter two Souldiers retiring, beaten in by three others, with them, the Lieutenant, holding Sophia in his hand.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: SLaves, you have her? you have your Throats shav'd with a short sword.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: By what title is she yours? We fought for her.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: And by our Laws you ought to stand to your Lot.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: By what Laws? By the Roman Law, you Rascals? broad-sword-law; besides she looks as if she were sweet and sound, which are things you'l scarce bring a President, to prove your interest by.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: We will not quit our shares for words; We have swords.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: And no money; Go ye Rascals: do you shew your teeth? Go, truss, be gone, to the next woods side, there speed with your Ploughs; do you threaten me with your cold Iron?

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: Your odds makes you presume, but if we meet you alone, o'th' Guard.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Then I'll cut thy Throat.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: No, we'll spare you that labour, and have yours cut.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I know thou art good at killing, by Attorney.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: S'death, come away, follow, We shall a have time.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: And that's all, but a wheel and a croud, that thy end can claim,—
How now? weeping? come, dry, dry; I'll be a Father to thee. Art honest?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Dare not you be honest too?

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Honest? Faith, pretty one, he that dares fight is as honest a Souldier as needs to be.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: O! ye Gods. She lies down

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: They are the prettiest kind of commodities, these women, that a man can deal in, there is nothing like 'em, but ready money.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, leave talking, and fall to, that we may have Here they put up their swords .your leavings.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Not a bit, go home to your Doll, and fall to your cold meat, friends.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: Hang her, she's old.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Speak reverently of her Age, the Jade brought great loads to our pleasure, in her youth, and must not be forgotten.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: O but this, Sir, has such an excellent face.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Away, you Rogues, old chins, and naked chins, Boys of the first beard, and find distinction? must your weak stomacks have face-sauce, before you can fall to? the sex (you Varlets) was enough, when I was young; and I confess they have been sad days with me, since the Face and Peticoat came in esteem: look where she lies, (what? weeping, pretty one? now if I should dote in my latter days, and draw in at my eyes a punishment, they say the Gods are just, and may, through my doublet, punish the sins of my youth— Hum, I'll think no more on't;— Faith I must kiss thee. He lies down and she rises.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: O Sir, be not so barbarous as to bring those dangers you have beaten hence; why do you lay such rude hands on me? Think you, the innocence of Maid and Virgin have no power to He lays hands on her .guard me?

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: A Maid! by my faith, its strange, I should ha' judged you at the second age, when women fall; have you no witness of what you say? I have no faith your witness, or I kiss. He still puls her.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Away, unhand me, and force me not to call down a Plague to guard me, scorn not my words, if thou dost this wickedness, thou wilt find the curse of an injur'd Maid strike as sure, as lightning, and as fatal; nor can all thy skill and courage defend thee, but despairs will find thee, and inhabit in thee, till thou art dissolv'd in the horrors of thy fear. But if this calm, which seems to allay He lets her go and looks on her .thy troubled blood, be real, upon my knees, I'll fall, and to the Gods send my Prayers for thee, and they'l prove as great a guard, and thou shalt find this good act interpose between thee and thy greatest dangers.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: By this light she talks unhappily, should I keep her company, I must beg; no more of this discourse, pray.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Let me be safe in my Honour, and I'll be silent, and beside the reward that heaven will pay you, my Ransom shall be what you'l name.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: You have prevail'd, and shall be free from force; but take heed of talking of Heaven before these; to tempt them with such promises, is bidding them to their loss; for what can such fellows hope for there, but to become some odd Saints without Holy-daies?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: Lieutenant, you are somewhat free in your Opinion of us.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Why, dost thou sweet heart, hope for better? look upon him has he not a promising face? Ile prophecy, Crabb, continue in thy calling, and thou art safe, for thou hast endeavoured long, and I fear not, but hast made good friends below, and mayst be of a good rank in hell.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: Faith, Lieutenant, me thinks, you spurr'd fairly forwards, and, upon my Conscience, will be richly damn'd.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Who I? Faith and troth I think I shall, and yet, while Shakes his purse .this lasts, I have good hopes; for I am of Opinion, no Man is damn'd that has money in his purse; nor do I see how poor folks can be saved; What noise is that?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: I hear our Captains voice.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Away, take her to my quarter, and, upon your lives, no Insolence; pray step off with them, till I see what occasions this noise.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.l: I will go, But if this be Treachery
Know, though 'tis easie to abuse the Gods,
Yet it is heavy for to bear their rods.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Away, you are safe.

div.head: ACT. I. SCEN. II.
div.stage: Enter Captain and Souldiers, with the Romans bound, that were taken with Sophia.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: SIR, these are some poor Rogues.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Hang 'em then for being poor.

sp.speaker: 1. Roman.
sp.p: Cannot our praiers find thy Mercy?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A pox upon your prayers, they could not protect thee; hang 'em I say.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Hold Sir, mistake not these Men, for, if I guess right, they are no beggars.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Bring the Torture then.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: I believe, I know a way to gain the Truth without a Rack: There is a Wench—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I, What became of her?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: She's in my power, and talks not like a beggar; by this day, she threatned me, and frighted me from my pleasure, she profer'd a Ransome too, things that beggars never dream on.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Where is she? We will load her with chains, till they confess.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p:
Patience a little, and Ile instruct you; do but threaten
to kiss her, (you understand me) and, upon my life, she'l tell all.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: To the Dungeon then with these, and fetch her; but dost thou hear, Lieutenant, is she likely? is it a handsome Wench? dost thou see ready money in her face?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: O, 'tis a proper Wench, and bravely built, such Eyes, so black, so great, of a Beauty that is currant every where, Then her Cheeks, and such Lipps; ha! by this hand I could ha dwelt for ever there.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: She came luckily for this Mart; what became o'th Boyes we took a swimming in Baio?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: They are safe, and will be ready for the same fraight.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And all will scarce quit cost.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Faith Captain, we have no luck of late, our old Souldiers are immortal too, they will not die, there comes no profit that way of late; When the Moor was Captain, in his years there fell as many of those rotten plums, as were worth ten thousand Drachms.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And since my reign, I cannot count a thousand. The young Cicilian, the bold Cilius, is returned too, and now I have no hope to continue another year.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Which? he that was the Prisoner?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, the same, his hopes stand fair for the next Election, nor shall I envy him if he gain it, for it's a gallant Fellow, and indeed ought to command here.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Faith Captain, a competent ill nature (I thank the Gods) I have gain'd in the service, and to me 'tis indifferent who is Captain, for I must be Lieutenant still, till my lot falls, and yet I have so much gratitude as to be angry with old Tullius.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why dost thou blame a Man for desiring to live?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: By my Faith, when a Man desires it so unreasonably, I do; he knows he cannot live, and yet he has not so much good nature as to die; what if he may linger out this moneth? he'l die the next, and then your reign expires.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Marry, and the Villain is rich, and 'twere not amiss to be his Heir.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: If he die in time; but if he live he will not be worth one Drachma; for since they told him he could not escape, The slave that grudg'd himself Bread before eats Gold now, and considering you are his Heir, it is your Gold he eats; would I had such Title to his Estate, by this light, I'de choak him, slave.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Thou art in the right, if he die this moneth, I am his Heir, by the Laws of our Band, if next, he that succeeds; and I am certain, he made his Fortune under me.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Why I, there's the point, Faith Captain, if you please, Ile go speak with him, and try what good nature will do, it may be he'le hear reason, Ile urge how much he is bound to you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Thou mayst go, but I'me afraid it will be lost labour.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: A party of Romans taken, where? guide my hate, that with fatal wounds I may empty their proud veins.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How now Cilius, what Rage is this?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: O Teresius, can you be content, because our persons lie hid, to let our shames continue visible, and thus sleep out the sufferings of our Country? I past or'e her bosom in my Journey, Oh! had you, with me, seen the general calamities she groans under, ruin'd even to a Chaos, and the wretched people, grown so degenerate in their sufferings, that they begin, with joy, to obey the insulting Conquerour.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: It is wisdom now to obey.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Wisdom? Is Teresius grown so tame, to think so? let the Dogs, not Cilius, practise it.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why thus impatient?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Our Countrey and our miseries call for our swords to protect her, and to see you thus tame makes me so.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: This rage serves her as little— And 'tis now in vain to attempt their ruine, whose Conquest has taken such firm root.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Those that bled in the last battle thought not so.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: To what rash attempts would your rage guide you! is the sad issue of that day no example which our brave Prince Facertes was forced to survive, and adorn their Triumphs? But that being past, he had dy'd upon the Hook, nor could the Intercession of Virgilius letters have deferred the doom, though he bestrid him in the heat of battle, had not the far-fam'd Sophia, in his approaching Fate, call'd to mind that which he (though an Enemy) protected her Brother from, and in the instant kneel'd and embrac'd Caesars knees, divinely pleading, Pallas inspir'd her, and with her own Beauties cloath'd the Virgin, and with such power the Goddess moved in her, that when Caesar gaz'd upon her blew eyes he left to be Caesar, and rather obey'd then granted, and to be her Father could scarce secure him from being fettered with those white wrists which circled his imperial knees.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Was Virgilius then in the Power of Facertes, that day, and did he let him escape, did he fawn upon the Roman?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: It was but to return the Piety Virgilius shewed his Foster-father, who (you know) protected him in that sad day our King was slain, and, by his power, he grew able to give that last blow for his Countries Freedom, which when the aged Nigro saw inclining to the Romans, covetous to have his Age set in some glorious Act, he charg'd the youthful Virgilius, but or'e loaded with Courage, his silver hairs sunk under the Roman, whose Piety bestrid him like his Father, vowing to sacrifice upon that breast, sooner then wound it.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: 'Twas done like the Son of the first Julius; These are degenerate, and succeed onely in the others Fortune, not his Merit, Yet— had I been by—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What could your single Arm have done?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Kill'd Virgilius, in Revenge of the Rape the Roman Ploughes has made upon my Mothers womb. For other Parent then my Country, I yet could never find. Oh! that I had been that day with the brave Facertes, who knows but I might have digg'd a glorious Monument in some lucky wound, given in the face of this admir'd Virgilius, and after such a Fortune, I could have smil'd, and, unshook, step'd into my graye. Or if slav'd, such bold truths I would have utter'd, they should not have destroy'd me for cold Example, but rather because Rome durst not let me live. And yet I beg if there be any Power favourable to Cilius, let it set within my swords reach this Virgilius, this King of Men, This Sicilian scourge, that makes us kneel and kiss our Afflictions; Then, then, Teresius, thou shalt see, how with this sword Ile hunt his pale Soul to her last home.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: 'Tis a Gallant Youth, how his Spirit boyles, to be in Action.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: If I be chose Captain of our Band, by all our bondag'd Gods, in some disguise, Ile see that Rome, I will Teresius, and with a few wounds well dealt, gather a numerous Revenge; say, would not you obey, if I command, to joyn in such a Sacrifice, where, to fall, The Off'ring is as glorious, as to stand the Priest, and such attempts are becoming Sacrifice for Men, let Women incense burn, it is properer for us to expiate with wounds, then Prayer or Fasting, and had those we vainly dealt in Sacrifice been given upon our Enemies, our Heards had now been fair, and Rome Ashes.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: May all thy thoughts prove Prophetick, and here I vow to obey what ere thou injoynest.— Though it be not safe to let thee know the Reason, nor the Interest thou hast in thy Countries sufferings.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Sir, will you come to the Examination, The Prisoners are at the Quarters.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: What Prisoners?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The Romans.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Why are they not stak'd?

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: There's a Woman amongst'em.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You will not stake her, will you?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: No, I make no war with Women.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: If she must die, I beg the staking of her.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: What is she?

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: More then young, and handsome, and one that talks unhappily; I know not—

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Ile go see her; Captain, Ile meet you at the Oak.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ile to my Quarter, and attend you.

sp.speaker: Virgil.
sp.p: O Let me stretch my self, and thus enlarg'd possess my Joyes; for know, my longing Soul made a Crown a Burthen, and with greater joy I have put off an Empire, then thou thy chaines; and now transported with my hopes, the Bird that from the Cage is flown, and broke that Prison, where she was wont to mourn, and sings all Tunes at once, That Bird, I say, cuts not the yielding Air with more joyful Freedom, then I, to find my self, and deliver'd from that imprisoning state.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Sir, Thus far I have obeyed your Commands, which enjoyned me to accompany you from Gallia hither: But what your design should be, that makes you thus, with Joy, quit your Command there, and be pleased to find your self unknown and hid in a disguise at Naples, I cannot guess, nor shall I be so rude to ask; for sure if it were fit I knew it, you, that dare trust your sleeping self in my power, would not hide it from me.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Doe's not my Friend guess, whither I am bound?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Not the particular; but I am certain 'tis some great design, to conquer which, you thus in ambush lay the great Virgillius.

sp.speaker: Virgil.
sp.p: The Body was made the Souls slave, and now but serves her to advance my ends; nor is my Mind less, or thoughts more subject to fear, then when an Army compass'd me.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Sir, That you are alone makes you not less in my esteem; for it is not your power I admire, (the loss of mine own tells me, that's mortal) but your Mind; which, when Virgilius is nothing but what my Memory gives life to, will make me worship his Monument.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: No more, Prince Facertes, my Friend, and to confirm him take a secret, by which Ile bind him to me for ever; for secrets have stronger ties then Love, or Vowes; for whilst thou hast Honour that binds thee, the other may by mistake or Passion (which Friendship's self is subject to) fall even to hate.

sp.speaker: Facertes.
sp.p: Then, when I have honour, I shall know your design.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: When thou hast! O Facertes, my friend, it was born with thee; and where it is not natural, swords cannot acquire it; Take therefore into thy heart all the secrets of mine, and in a word, all my hopes, and all my fears, Cicilia.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: What of her, Sir?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: She is all my hopes, all my wishes, and all my fears; and if she smile, I am fortunate: for know, my journey is to lay at her feet my self, and all that Conquest gave me. What thinks Facertes? will she accept it, and not destroy the destroyer? For nothing can be conquest, where she suffer'd, but height of Murther.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p:
What, do I hear my prayers forestall'd, and those joys Our Country ought to sacrifice for, offer'd to us? I hope Virgilius
is not still pleased to triumph or'e our miseries, and throw a scorn upon that, which he thought worthy of his sword?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Have you not yet forgiven what was my fate? while these thoughts dwell in thee, I must not hope Facertes will joyn the power of a Brother to assist my wishes.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: If you are real, you shall tread upon my neck, but if this be scorn, 'tis so unlike my friend, and so unbecoming the brave Virgilius, that I should not fear to call him enemy, nor despair his conquest.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Real, Facertes! why when have I jested with my friend? Real? yes, as thy vows to Sophia. Never start, nor put on amazement, was I less worthy of a trust, because thou thought'st me worthy to have been thy enemy? call me friend, and hide thy love? Either thou hast not found the knowledge, or lost the value of thy friend: I tell Prince Facertes, she, whom he sacrificeth to, has greater ties upon me as Friend then Sister.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: That I do love the divine Sophia, witness my part of heaven, which is all thou hast left me to swear by; but if thou hast gain'd the knowledge of that secret, by jealous guesses, purchas'd treachery, or with thy power hast wrought upon her sex to betray her innocent affection, draw thy sword, for, by all our Gods, no Facertes draws his sword. distance, as enemy, nor neerness of Friendship shall divide us, or secure thee from my vengeance.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I am innocent, and you are angry; here read that, it will tell you, you have injur'd me. He gives Facertes a Letter.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Can Virgilius pardon me, and still have patience to learn me how to conquer Nations first, and then my self, by his great Example?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p:
Your friendship I shall never decline; and if Sophia be just, you have a warrant for you faith of mine. When I went for Gallia to take command of those Legions there, at parting, we fell into discourse of you, and the never-enough-admir'd Cicilia, whose beauties and vertues she always mention'd with admiration: I confessed to her, that her former descriptions had engaged my affections to your Sisters fame so much, that I was resolved, in some disguise, to see her. O're-joyed with this news, she recommended you to me for a guide, And though I ever admir'd the honour I found in Facertes, yet I confess, I made a little stop ere I resolved to put my self in the power of one, whom I had tempted with such a ruine, as obeying my Fathers injunctions, had made me lay upon your suffering Country; to remove which doubt she blushed out this secret; I ask'd her then, why she suffer'd thee to be led in triumph? she said, she pleaded against it, what she durst, and had she loved less, she could have said more, but seeing her own guilt, she fear'd it might have been trouble to all: Now if this truth can satisfie Facertes, that I have not wrong'd him, and now I beg, he'l give me leave to return his vows, to Cicilia; and now I conjure thee by that power which thou hast given her, in Sophia's name, here to bury all thy fears, all thy anger, all remembrance that I was a misfortune to thee, in return of which upon thy breast, the
Altar of friendship, I'll lay mine a sacrifice, and vow my self to fair Cicilia, and her Country, a constant friend.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, The joys you load your slave with, I wish you may find, when you sigh under such a pleasing burthen, as the enjoying all your wishes brings. And if my prayers be prosperous, Virgilius will prove our Physitian, and the wounds he gave, but Prescriptions, and we have bled for our health only.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: From hence then, I'll count my conquest over Facertes, and think I have brought more strength to our Empire, by his friendship, then his Country.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: If you intend a sudden journey, give me leave to furnish you with a Galley, I have some acquaintance in the Town; I'll dispatch, and meet you presently upon the Mould: will you not send, to see whether your Sister be arriv'd at Baio?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Yes, and we'll touch there, as we go.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: When I kiss'd her hands, to go for Gallia, she said, she was immediately to retire to Baio.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: We need not bid each other haste, since Love's our guide.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: HItherto, fair one, your beauty has preserved you; but let not your pride teach you, from success, to scorn a proffer'd love, that brings safety with it; for me, I confess I durst not enter where that beauty guarded; there was something in that Angel from that stroke me, and I boast a wound received from you, more then a conquest over another.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: This Act shews you truly valiant, and this fear, you pay the Gods, is courage: Fools and Cowards only dare their power, and you shall find success and conquest still await you, when you strike not against them; and my prayers shall invert the kind of this offering, and make a sacrifice of that which is duty: and you shall receive a reward for paying, as if you had given Hecatombs.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Faith, pretty one, I am pleas'd with what you say, though I understand it not, Pray, what kind of place is yours, in heaven? By this hand, I think she keeps the sweet-meats, or else, is woman Butler there.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, I am so mortal, I am subject to you: for heaven, I know it not, but by faith, and that tells me, when I am injur'd, my curses wound, and when served, my prayers heal.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Then you have nothing to shew, under the hands of those, what do ye call'um? those Gods?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nothing, but the examples of their justice; which, with punishment, visit the wicked.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p:
Now do I begin to find, I was a fool, and this wench a talker, By this hand I thought she had had some of the Gods in Liveries, at her Elbow, and there's no such thing, all is but a dream; He offers to kiss her.
but I'll be no longer fool'd by my fears. Faith, pretty one, let's try whether they be at leisure, or no; or if they be, they cannot have the face to punish us for those faults they were so subject to themselves.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: They are in a sad condition, that instead of repentance, seek examples for their sins; and the second is worse then the first; as insolence, is worse then weakness: why do you lay such rude hands upon me, You will not destroy what you have built?

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Wait without.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Are you there? Then I am prevented, a Pox upon my Cilius gazes upon her. tender nature, this it is to be ignorantly wicked, and subject to fits of conscience.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Lieutenant, is that the Prisoner, you spoke of?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Thou liest.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: I tell thee, its false, its here the Prisoner stands. Touches himself.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: That's she, I spoke of.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Leave us then.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Ye Gods, new miseries.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Why so; there's but three steps to a womans bed, liking, alone, and consent. Two of them he has past already, if she consent, I would he might pay her: look how they gaze, This is Love, and I have bought wit, But if a long staff keep me from the next, let 'em geld me.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Fair one, what Country boasts these Beauties?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Sir, I can answer for my self, But for those Beauties, you speak of, let them find a friend, I have misfortunes enough to busie my time, and I find it business enough to make it appear fit to live: The thoughts of beauty, are fit for those that have fortunes like their faces, and if mine be like my fortune, (as a friend I counsel you) not to let your eyes dwell longer here, for its a dangerous habitation, Not safe to me, that am native there, and I should mourn more for your dangers, then mine own, for I know how to be just, but I could never find, how to be fortunate.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: A Curse find him, and all pass'd Plagues be but stor'd for him, that would seek to deface that Temple, and what ere your modesty can urge.— Thus I'll pay my duty, for I know, such a He kneels to her .worship can be no new thing to the Deity, that's shrowded in their eyes.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: If you kneel, I must kneel too, for the guilt is no less to take a worship where it is not due, then to pay it. She kneels likewise.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: But if the guilt be equal, pray refuse not to receive an unfeigned one.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I dare not rise, while you kneel; for although the fault be equal, yet civility makes this fitter. They both rise.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p:
I'll not dispute; for know, should you command, through sin, I'de serve you; and therefore you may be confident, I'll obey you, when you command me shun it; and here, with shame, I confess, I came prepar'd with lust, hungry with sin, and look'd to
have met a sacrifice to me.— But I have found the power, and now return as from the Altar, struck with holy despairs, and shall feed on what I have already fed my eyes and ears with.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Sir, I find there's honour in your brest, but I fear that safety dwells not every where; for the Souldier that you found with me, repents him of the good that saved me.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: He dares as soon suck in a Pestilence, as breathe on that air, I frown in; he is my slave, and to my will his fate is tied, if he dares breathe ought but obedience, 'tis his own sentence; say, fairest, shall he live, By our Gods (but to serve you) he should not. What, ho! Lieutenant, Sirrah, what was it you said, to disturb this calm.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Faith little Sir, something that tended to the use of handsome women.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Slave, didst thou look upon her, and not kneel? by her self, I swear (purer then which our Temples shew nothing) if any act or word of thine shall henceforth pay less reverence here, then at the Altar, thou art Earth; mark me; this shall wound the into Earth. He lays hand on his sword.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Sir it shall, and I'll call it justice, death has taken six I think, and is drunk with her beauty, a pox upon me: I must be praising her forsooth.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Sir, you need not threaten, the reward is not worth the hazard, and I am safe.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: The reward! oh, that it were to be purchas'd at the rate of Kingdoms, then the sword might gather those Beauties! but they are neither within the compass of conquering, nor dying for, else I durst say, after all my wounds and triumphs, see your slave; but now I am lost in my despairs.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Sir, Truth has such affinity with truth, that I can scarce hide one from you, which I fear will be displeasing.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: To serve you, is the first thoughts of my heart, and since I cannot, my self be happy, let me contribute my Power to make you so; dare you tell me who you are?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: A vow forbids me.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: Sir, the Captain expects you.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Me? I'll wait him presently: Lieutenant, see you cheerish your first act, and with honour treat this Lady, and you shall command me; your pardon, fair one, our Captain commands me hence, but you shall be safe from all dangers, but what your sadness brings, and I shall be proud to be call'd yours, though despis'd.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Witness heaven, all that honour can spare me is yours; And therefore I beg you will not injure me, to say I despise you: When we have not, we cannot pay, and I shall mourn to think I must dye your Debtor.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Madam, But I can admire and sacrifice in thoughts, pray command me to do something for you, oh! that these five tedious days were wasted, that, without a treachery, I might say, you are free, but if you can find a strength to resist these miseries, till then, By our Gods, you are as free as they, and as readily I'll obey you.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Sir, your first bounties make me happy; and since I have your protection for my Honour, all the rest, when they are blown over, bring but a pleasure in the relation.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: I must go— There is a necessity that forces me to obey, I cannot else command your safety.— Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Need I say again, Protect this Lady?

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: No Sir, By this hand, he hath gelt me with a look, Madam, will it please you to walk?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Yes Sir, Ile follow you, and I hope I shall not be asham'd to follow my Facertes, whose Soul, I think, holds Intelligence with this Souldier; and were it not that I been accustomed to see such Virtue, this would start me.

div.head: ACT. II. SCEN. I.
div.stage: Enter Nigro wounded, and Cicilia holding him by the Arm

sp.speaker: Nigro.
sp.p: FLy, oh fly, and save your self, Madam, This Piety will give wings to your Innocence; for it is just, ye Powers, A noise of fighting within .by Miracle, to save that Miracle.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: No Father, The fears and nicities of our Sex I have long since banish'd hence; and so many have been my dayes of mourning, that I thought not to have shed a tear for any new misery; But this is a loss I could not foresee, and by surprize this grief has got into my heart, look, if I have not tears left.— Oh! ye Heavens, Where is that Justice and Mercy we sacrifice to? Why were you absent when his sword strooke in your own cause? He faints. Wounds, and Age! There is a kind of Sacriledge in this Murther, and I could be wicked in my anger, to see his faithful youth preserv'd thus to a punishment, and, instead of a reward, see him pursu'd like the wicked, and his Age set in Blood.

sp.speaker: Nigro.
sp.p:
O excellent Maid! let not my ruine beget faults in thee; A noise within .nor do thou thus repine at the last and greatest of my Honours; is it not better to sink thus, Then blushing say I surfeited, or go shaking out with an Ague, like a Coward School-Boy, to my Grave! Fairest, I have been bred a Souldier; and had it been as noble to yield as conquer, I could have died as easily, as kil'd.— Your Hand, Madam, for I find I faint, Why should I grieve to die, that have this to lay me in the Earth! O weep not, By this last smile I conjure you, weep not; But let your sadness die, and my Memory live; For witness that power, to whom I am now offring my self, as my last Sacrifice, I have all that dying Nigro could wish; am I not blest with my Countries cause to die in, while a Princess mourns at my Funeral, and an Angel Virgin is
He swounds. She looks sadly upon him.
They seize Cicilia . sent to close mine Eyes.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: He's dead.—

div.stage: Enter the Vice-Roy and Souldiers, the Vice-roy is wounded and taken, he falls.

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.p: Hands off, This is my Prisoner.

sp.speaker: 2. Sould.
sp.p: She's finely built, I think she was furnished for the Mart.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: Ile have her Cloathes, I spy'd them first.

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.p: Ile have her, and let whose will take the rest; I desire but to be lost in the wood with her, for a night, and let him take her that finds her in the morning.

sp.speaker: 2. Sould.
sp.p: He were a bold fellow, that would come after thee.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: Come, leave this squabling, lest the Lieutenant come, and then you get not a bit.

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.p: Faith, and thou art in the right, and I confess I would be glad to find a way to be revenged for the last he took from us.

sp.speaker: 3. Sould.
sp.p: I could tell you how to do it, and profitably too, if you would all take my counsel.

sp.speaker: 2. Sould.
sp.p: Propose, propose.

sp.speaker: 3. Sould.
sp.p: Then quit your thoughts of this dainty bit, and lets away with her, and the rest, to Naples, and sell 'em, This fine Points to Cicilia .thing shall yield Money, that will buy Wine, and Wenches, that bring no fears along with 'em; This gay thing, should we touch her forbidden fruit, we were damn'd; and we are sure, our Lieutenant will pursue us with fire and sword.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed, Agreed.

sp.speaker: 3. Sould.
sp.p: Thus rigg'd then, lets away, But we had best leave one to tell our Captain we are put to Sea, in pursuit of a Galley that bore the Roman Eagle, that will take off suspition while we are absent; then we may return, and say, they out sail'd us.

sp.speaker: 2. Sould.
sp.p: Ile stay, but remember my share.

sp.speaker: 3. Sould.
sp.p: What, dost thou think we are Thieves amongst our selves? Come, help draw these dead Bodies into the Wood, we'l bury them when we return.

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.p: Bring her away too, and take care of her, lest she spoil her self, and undo our Market.

sp.speaker: 3. Sould.
sp.p: Come, pretty one.— Nay, you must part. She sits by the body of Nigro all this while.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: Fools, you pull on your Fates, and labour to steal that Vengeance that would find you were you hidden in the Earth; and my Prophetick Soul tells me, I go but to see you punished.

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.p: What saies she?

sp.speaker: 2. Sould.
sp.p: I know not what she saies, but I hope she lies; do you hear, what kind of Women are your Witches?

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.p: A pox, they are old, Come Mistress, Dangers and handsome Women dwell not together; if they do, let me fall into them.—

div.head: ACT. II. SCEN. I.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: WHat were those Romans, that fell to my share?

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: They were taken when the pretty Wench was taken, that Cilius would have had.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Did you deliver 'em to the Lieutenant, and bid him come hither with his Accompt?

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: I left 'em there, and bid him come to your Worship, but I found him a little troubled, he had been at the Souldiers; but the fellow is wilfull.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But I have taken an order to bring him to Reason.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Whorson Clown, refuse to pledge me or die; Rascal, neither drink, nor die. Umh.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How now, Lieutenant, what passion's this?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Rogue, refuse to dye, or drink my Captains health, at my suit, and yet confess a Beer-glass would kill him.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Oh! is that the cause?

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: I'll swear, he is very unreasonable.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And ought to be put to death, for refusing a health.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: That was spoke like my Captain, and I'll kiss his foot, nay, nay, do not hold me, let me go, let me go, I say, that I may kneel, and wish thou maist live, till I refuse a Beer-glass.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What hast thou there?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: A Julip. He has a little bottle in his hand.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What are the ingredients?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Simple Aqua-fortis, to warm his stomack. Dog, offer to live, when wine is a poyson to him?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You shall not poyson him.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: No, I'll get his Doctor to prescribe it, and then 'tis Physick.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No, no poyson.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Then he'll live.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No I have prevented his living, for I was afraid thou wouldst not succeed. Thou hast no Oratory, thou canst not perswade, Then, thou art so subject to choller; Did you mark the old woman you met at my Quarter? it was his wife. In six words, I made a price with her, to kill him, without any of the difficulties you found in perswading him.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Captain, you are weak, Captain; I not Eloquent? your Argument is weak; Death, do you think 'tis no more to perswade one to dye, then to hire another to kill him.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Stand fair, and I'll confute you. Crabb.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: What wilt thou give me to kill him.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Come, leave your fooling, and give me your Accompt.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p:
Am I Eloquent then?
Lieu. offers to draw his sword.
The Lieu. pulls out a piece of dirty paper, and gives it him.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, yes, give me your Accompt, and I'll believe you Eloquent, what's this?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Your Accompt.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: My Accompt?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Yes, and an Eloquent Accompt.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What's here? paid, lent, given, and rests due; faith it's an Eloquent accompt indeed: But Lieutenant, is this all?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: All? why would you have more?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Kind Lieutenant, I would have an Accompt.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Why have you not an Accompt? All is but this over and over; but if you'l give it me again, you shall have a longer Bill.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But Lieutenant, Eloquent Lieutenant, is that all that's left of my four thousand Sestertia.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Why, what accompt should I make you? would you not pay what you owe? and lend a good fellow that drinks fair; or is your Charity dead to pretty sinners in their necessity, and militant in the world?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But grant these uses, what is the sum? what paid, what lent?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Why, what you will.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Very good. But what means this, Rests due, of whom must I enquire for that?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Of me Torrafuco, lodging at the sign of the Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Crabb, knock, and if the Party be within, tell him, I would speak with him, and require an Accompt of certain living creatures that were given to his trust, Women and Children.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: They, Sir, are encreas'd, the Moore has a Calf running by her side, of his own getting, the other Barbary is with Fole to; and she that you sent to day had like to have been leap'd in his Collar.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: The Alarm, Sir, is given, from the shore, and the Lyon is in chase of a Galley that bears the Roman Eagle, and Cilius waits directions at your Quarter.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Tell him, we come, and, do you hear, get the Leopards Gang ready; what will my careful Steward do, visit the sick? Pray, let the Prisoners be bath'd first, and well fed, against the Mart.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Crabb.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: Here, nobel Lieutenant, I am always ready to serve.— When he is in this humour I cleanse his Pockets, and that's my Revenue. Aside.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Crabb, talking is not good for me when this fit is upon me; for I find, I am subject to grow angry, weak and drowsie.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: Therefore you must master your passion, at first, ere it grow upon you; but there is no speaking to you when you are in an Argument.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: I find thee an able man, and therefore I'll lean upon thee: what's that, Crabb?

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: What's what, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: I felt a live thing in my Pocket, Crabb. Crabb, picks his pocket as he leans on him, he finds his hand in his pocket.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: It may be your worships breeches are torn.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: I will reward thy faith with a Trust, Crabb, here, to let thee see, how dear thou art to me, keep my Tobacco-box.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: Noble Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: No thanks, but help to lay me down behind some tree, in the shade.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: Your worships head is full.— I could have gelt him, the slave has drunk himself stiff.

div.stage: [Enter Crabb again with his money in his hat.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Crabb, Crabb. Lieu. as he lies holds up the Curtain, and calls Crabb.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: Here, here.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Prethee stick a bough for a mark, that thou maist find me again, lest I be lost in my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: I shall, I shall.

div.head: ACT. II. SCEN. II.
div.stage: Enter at one Door the Souldiers, with Cicilia and the rest of the Prisoners, to be sold; at the other Door a Pimp, and a she Baud.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: CAptain, a word with you, I have view'd your ware, but is there any special piece amongst 'em?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: As you see; they are young, and sound.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Will you give a trial?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: With the eye, and the tongue, question, or search them, nothing else.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Not a little freedom alone? you were not wont to be thus hard.

sp.speaker: 3 Sould.
sp.p: Faith, we have had no luck of late, Mistress, this is the first Mart we have made this moneth.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: And you come to our house, it shall cost you nothing.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: At what price do you hold that fine thing?

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: That? it is the cream of our Mart, she will cost two thousand Sestertia.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Is she a maid?

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: I'll warrant that, if I sell her.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Come, a thousand is fair, and take you the profit of the first night.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: No, altogether, or nothing, view her, she is worth the money naked.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: But, my friend, I hope you have try'd your self, ere now? are you fruitful? She speaks to one of the slaves.

sp.speaker: Slave.
sp.p: Yes, Mistress, and if you agree upon the price, you shall find me a faithful servant; and for the sport, if I raise you not a Crop from the Common, geld me.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Geld thee? Marry God forbid man; I'll lame thee first, art sound too? else I may live to curse your doings.

sp.speaker: Slave.
sp.p: Sound as a Bell, and as ever you hope to be satisfied, buy me. The slave bugs her.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Away, away, y'are a wag, is your breath sweet, let me smell, you are very forward, pray turn, and let's see your price, He kisses her .here Souldier, take your money.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: Thank you, may his back never fail you.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Faith, you are too dear.— Stay, here comes the Prince Bragadine, the Viceroys Son.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: How now, Souldier, what famous Prize is that?

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: A Greek Sir, a Virgin.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: What's her price?

sp.speaker: 1 Soul.
sp.p: Two thousand Sestertia.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: It's dear, and yet its a proper Wench.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: My Sister not arrived yet at Baio? its strange.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: No Sir, not yet, but she has been expected these ten dayes.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: What crowd is that?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: The slave-mart is held to day.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: What stranger is that?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p:
Was that fellow drunk?
As Virgilius comes in, he meets Bragadine going out, they justle, and look scurtily at one another.
Virgilius spyes Cicilia. and falls in Love with her.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Either drunk or worse.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Is that excellent piece to be sold?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: She is not, who can buy her? or who dares set a price upon that Beauty? Fairest, what Country is (at this time) cursed with your absence, for sure 'tis perpetual night when you are thence.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: Greece, Sir, is my Country, more particulars I must not tell.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Fools that we are, to call our selves Conquerours of Greece, when one slave, one handfull of that Earth, has power to conquer me, and lead me bound, even in my own Country.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: It is not becoming your youth, nor fortune (how great so ever) to make a scorn of those miseries which chance throwes upon the Innocent.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: A strange curse find me when I scorn you; dare you not tell me what you were before this ruine?

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: I must not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: And are there no statues fix'd in the Temples, or History, that preserves your Story? must all but your Beauty sink with this ruine?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: Sir, if you will buy her, take her upon her price; if not, The Souldier interrupts him. give others leave to bid.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Fool, thou canst not sell her, for thou know'st not how to value her, yet cozen thy self; what dost thou ask?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: Two thousand Sestertia.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: All! yes.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: And is she free when that is paid?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: Yes, if you please.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Madam, not to call you mine, but to have a power to appear yours, give me leave, with the loss of mine own, to find your Freedom. Go fetch two thousand Sestertia.— unbind her. Virgilius puts her chaines upon his arm.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: What mean you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: They are proper here; and I beg you will not refuse (when Honour consents) to release me.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: I hope my miseries will not beget Ingratitude in me, for I confess, 'tis some Joy in the midst of these troubles, to find that Honour that shines throughout this act; and though my bonds be as new and strange to me as your self, yet let me say, if there be a faulty thought that bids you hope to find a slaves heart here, you are deceived; for I would sooner sell my self to slavery, or, by a wound seek a freedom.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: By thy self, by thy Angel self, I approach thee with thoughts as pure and as constant as those our Vestals wait on the holy flame with; and but that I know you would scorn a Sacrifice that's offer'd by prophane hands, those Attributes are given to the Gods I'de kneel and pay to you.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Souldier, the Prince would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Which is that fine thing you spoke of? Above in the window appears Paulina and the Baud.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: That that the stranger stands by.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: That stranger, knowest thou that stranger?

sp.speaker: Baud,
sp.p: No, not I.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Now by the sins of my youth, 'tis a God-like form!— Why do they pull the Woman so? The Souldier returns, and layes hold on Cicilia.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: How now, unhand her Villain, is she not free?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: You have not pay'd your money, and I must not lose my Market you talk'd, and another ha's gon through with the bargain.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Another, what other?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: One that will find the way to her Sex, before you'le come to kissing her hand: take her away.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Slave, dost thou glory in thy Villanies?— There, now let Virgilius stabbs him. him that dares claim her follow me and take her.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: What have you done, Sir?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Fairest, begun a Justice I hope the Gods will finish. The rest of the Souldiers draw and call for help. Murther.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: How, kill'd! whose act is this?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Mine, and I'le answer it; some one that knew him follow me, and take the money for this Lady.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: That Woman I have paid for, and I will not quit my purchase; either yield her, or I shall force her.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I know what 'tis command, but never yet heard that voice (unless an Oracle) that I would have obeyed when the Speaker frowned, and thou lookst not like him whose voice is thunder.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p:
Gallant Youth.
He layes hold of her.
He strikes him and draws.
Bragadine and the Souldiers draw.
They fight.
Enter Souldiers arm'd.
Exeunt Omnes.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: I cannot talk, Sir, but I shall take my own.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Touch her not, yet I have patience, let her alone.— Nay, if you will be insolent, I'le punish it if I can.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: Kill the Dog.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Hold Sir, as you have any sense of Honour, hold for shame, betray not thy Fame so poorly as to let a slave share in thy Revenge; this base odds calls thee Coward, though thou conquerest.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: Who made you a Judge of mine Honour?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: So, I fear you'le find your Treachery no guard.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: This way, this way he is gone, seize her and secure her to the Princes house, whilst we follow him.

div.head: ACT. II. SCEN. III.
div.stage: Enter Virgilius, and the Souldiers after him.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: VIllains, whither tends your Rage?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: To revenge: yield, or thou art dead.

sp.speaker: Paulina above.
sp.p: Slaves, leave to pursue that stranger, or I'll send those shall shake your wretched souls out of their Cases.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: What's she?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: What ere you are that thus have lent your pity to a stranger, in distress, may you never know what 'tis to want a pity.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: To buy a slave?

sp.speaker: 3 Sould.
sp.p: Upon him, alive or dead, we'll have him.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Ha! the Prince engag'd, draw.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: HEll upon you all, where were your Mercenary swords when they should assist? S'death, to let a single stranger, in mine own door, brave me, and none by, to kill the dog? who now is escaped, to brag that he snatched from Bragadine a slave that he bought and paid for.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: Sir, we could not Prophesie, your Highness would go out; and none call'd us; But for the slave, she is at home, and safe, The Sailers brought her, and are now in pursuit of the stranger.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: If she be safe, let's lose no time, but follow them, lest he escape, with his glories, which which way went they?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: This way, Sir.

div.head: ACT. III. SCEN. I.
div.stage: Enter Virgilius, Facertes, and Minetes in rage, for the loss of Cicilia.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: HOw do you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Not well.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: What accident was this?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p:
Oh! Facertes, I have seen my Fate, and I conjure thee by all our friendship, not to call me weak, nor dispute with my passion, but obey thy friend, and suddenly, or I am lost for ever; for her innocence, I fear, will be no guard against their power; and without impiety I may mistrust the Gods, for they already have slept, and let her fall into misery; oh, Facertes, I am a slave to a
slave, and to hers my Fate is bound. And Temples, not chains are due to her; and when thou seest her thou wilt forgive me this change, for she has a Beauty against which thy honour must arm, else thy love will be no more a guard then was my resolution.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: All this for a slave!

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Oh! do not revile her; for when thou meet'st her, thy wonder and repentance will make but one thought, and like me thou wilt be lost in a maze.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: This is strange.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I confess it; yet when the world was innocent before the bloody sword taught her pride by conquest, and learn'd the thirsty wooll to drink the purple dye, till it grew enrich'd with the far-fetch'd stains, such innocence and beauty as waits on her might any where have claim'd a sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Sir, though I grant all these beauties, yet to me they bring like miseries to those the swift lightning leaves the wretched husband-man; who instead of full joys, reaps from those wounding fires nought but weighty griefs; yet I'll obey you, though in this chance I foresee my own despairs, to the little hopes I had of happiness. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Why do you conclude so? must you of necessity be miserable, if I be happy? are my friends joys the less, 'cause mine are full?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir, if you find me troubled to see all my hopes wither'd, and those wounds you gave my suffering Country now despairing of a cure.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: O friend! friend! has that word no power?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Yes, and that makes me sleight my interest; for I am so accustomed to misfortune, 'tis almost natural to me: But when I think on whom you throw your fortune, youth and fame, I find a greater trouble as your friend, then as I am the lost Facertes; for you know not what she is; your love hunts thus in the dark, A slave, a thing set at sale for lust. Virg. offers to go away.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: That, that, Facertes makes me rage; and again by all that's powerful I conjure thee fly with me to her rescue, before such a ruine find her.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Virgilius, Sir, Virgilius stay; I must obey him, or he's lost.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Draw thy sword then, and let me see thee plead with that against her enemies, as thou didst against me at Siracusa, and I'll conclude all hopes from that powerful Argument.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Sir, I never us'd my Arguments to spare my sword; nor was my tongue now drawn, because I meant that should sleep: See 'tis drawn, but in vain you hope a service from it, as your self; and therefore stay here, while I fit you with a disguise.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Be speedy then. As Virg. and Minetes are going out they meet the Baud, Olympia.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: I shall, but pray retire a little, this place is too publick, I'll return immediately.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I'll stay at the corner.—

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: May I be bold?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: With you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p:
Sir, your pardon.
He offers to go away, but she takes hold of him.
He offers her money.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: For what? I forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Sir, I would beg.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Here, I'll prevent thee, if thou wilt let me go.—

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: No, Sir, my business is no money; 'tis your self must satisfie me.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Thou art mistaken sure, thy business was to my man.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: No, Sir, I go upon no such Errands. Did you not fight for a slave even now?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Yes, what of her?

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Are you he?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Yes, I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Farewell then, till you are at leisure.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Prethee stay.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: No, Sir, your man is busie.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Prethee excuse my trouble, which gave not ear to thee at first.

sp.speaker: Paulina above.
sp.p: That's he, why stays she so long to deliver her Message? she is angry.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: For once I excuse; you and look hereafter you entertain a woman with more: But to the business; the slave you wot of— (oh! that eye of yours) there lies a wag in't that will make a world of mischief,) you know not who it hath struck, pray heaven I get not a wound.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Nay, to your story, good Mother, and leave this wandring.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Mother? whose Mother, good-man boy? I am a Maid.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: You mistake me, I meant, Mother of my joys, and so you will be if you can lay by this youthful fire that makes you thus subject to choler, and proceed with your story.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Yes, yes, do you jeer me?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: I can endure no longer; Sir, what ere you are, take my faith for your safety, and make this house your sanctuary; something concerning that slave I would deliver to you.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Are you there, Hell and mischief find you.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Madam, who ere you are that offers this charity to a stranger; know, I dare enter though I saw my ruine in the door. For fear I never found his pale den yet, though I have oft trod those paths that led both to dangers and to death; and I should scorn my self, could I apprehend him now where beauty has the guard. Which way do your commands guide me?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: That door.

div.stage: [Ex. Virg. and his man, and Paul. from above.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p:
Now a publique Pox go with thee, that thy face may serve thee in no stead; malicious Villain, to call up my dead fears that had wont to tell me I had lost my time; proud scurvey fellow, to put me thus in despair; and if he had any good nature, he would have offer'd me a kindness, in courtesie to have comforted
me; I shall not eat to day; had he but call'd me Whore, yet it had been tolerable, for that carries youth with it. But old Mother? Rascal, none of thy Mother. But I'll be reveng'd.

div.head: ACT. III. SCEN. II.
div.stage: The Lieutenant appears under the Hanging, and Nigro by him groaning.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: CRabb, Crabb.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Crabb, what's that groans?

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: Help, help for charity, more wounds, or remedy.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Ha! what's that? help, where am I? 'tis a man making his will, I'll be his heir, ha! what's here? a man wounded? this is that Rogue, Crabb; he has robb'd him, and laid him here to make me accessary.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: Help, if you have charity.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: With all my heart, and prethee, do me the favour to live till we come to my Quarter.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: If I do, I shall discover something pleasing to you.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Marry, I'll carry thee, for thy testimony, there is nothing else in this case can save me.— You are no Rogue, Crabb! Who did this?

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: Not he.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: That's good evidence for me.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Nor I, by this hand, you must quit me, while you can speak.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: I acquit you both.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Witness, witness, Crabb.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: Where did you find him?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Find him? by this hand, he found me and lay down by me, as I was asleep.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: Why, faith he is going a long journey, and came to take you with him, Thou art good company; but to leave this discourse, take my business: Our Captain would have you go visit the sick party, and see whether he will be perswaded yet or no to dye.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: I hate to see the Rogue; I have such battels in my head, since morning, yet I'll go, while I am neer him, and take you charge of this old man in the mean time, and see him carefully drest.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: So, lean upon me, what Rogues were these to use an old man thus?

sp.speaker: Souldier
sp.p: WHo's there?

sp.speaker: within Lieu.
sp.p: Where is this old fellow, is he alive still?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Bring him out, to take a little fresh air.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Is he come again? why did you let him in? he'll be a lasting a tedious affliction to me.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: How now? how is't, how is't man?

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Neither live nor die in peace?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Yes, dye in as much peace as you can.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: When my time comes; but I hope a man may have leave to live out his days; my Physitian says, I may escape yet.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Your Physitian's an Ass, and you give him too great Fees.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: He tells me I may escape this fit, if I can recover mine enemies; for he assures me, my greatest danger is my heir.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Doe's he say so? I cry him mercy then, he is a knowing man, I believe so too: and you may, perhaps, at a great charge, recover; but, in my opinion, you had better dye, and take our prayers with you; for to recover would but incense the Captain, and lose your friends.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Sure my Captain would be loath to lose me; he ever loved me.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Why I; and yet you refuse him to dye, and think much to hasten your journey a day or two, for his sake.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Alas, I would be glad to serve my Captain in any thing that lies in my power, I'll pray for him, and I hope he will excuse me for desiring to live, and serve him.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: You may flatter your self, but I'll assure you, he takes it very ill at your hands, that you, of all his company, should refuse him such a kindness, nay, not to appear willing to do it, if it were in your power; But thus, with an unnecessary charge, endeavour to live, crossing the disease that would be friend him.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Alas, I do nothing to cross it, I do but suffer.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Will you promise me that, and let the disease alone, it will be some satisfaction to him, and to us that are your friends, to see that you endeavour to satisfie him.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: That I'll promise you: and from henceforth I'll seek no remedy, but put my self into the hand of his friend, as you call'd it.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Then you shall see how carefully we'll provide for you; for I hope you do not think, that we or he desires this, because he is loth you should live two or three days; for what were that to him, but that he is to go out then; and the next Captain will be your heir.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, how can I help it? 'tis against my will, if any body be my heir.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Well, look you keep Covenants, and endeavour to dye finely; banish your Physician and gelly-broth, I'll provide noises to keep you waking. Crabb, provide two Drums to beat here their watch a piece; and do you hear, beware of a good diet.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: As you have charity, let me rest, those Drums are Daggers to me.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Nay, you'll be unreasonable again, I see it.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Oh misery of wealth!

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: I Confess, my first thoughts were like my self, faulty: but now I have gained by losing a desire, and I shall serve you faithfully in your love.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: All my fears are, that he will violate her.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: He dares not do it, I have conjur'd him from it, and when it may serve you, I'll boast my power, though purchas'd with a fault; and though your virtue secur'd you from that power, yet where sin has interest, mine never wanted a Command; and I know he dares not stand those frowns which your goodness melted into tears.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: No more, when we have sighed for our faults, they vanish with the same air; yet I fear him, though I believe your power great; for he that dares be a coward will stop at no wickedness within his reach.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: I made him asham'd of that base act, and vow not to pursue you; yet I counsel you not to stay long in this Town after you have her.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: What time did he appoint to bring her?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: He parted hence just as you entred, with a promise immediately to return; and if he should find you here, I am afraid it would prejudice my power to serve you; else I should rejoyce to be seen where so much honour dwells.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Your civilities and mercies, Madam, shewed to me, a stranger, I shall with a grateful mention acknowledge through the world; pray, what time will your commands enjoyn my return?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: It will not be safe, Sir, to come at all; But pray be pleas'd to send a friend after dinner, and you shall have notice of his first departure, what time that will be; yet I know not, for I am so miserable, I cannot now be good, but with a wicked pretence, There is another door leads into a street less frequented then that you entred at.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Which way must I take to find it?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: I'll guide you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: IT is well, happy discovery; now I shall be reveng'd at full; was it not enough to have his pride throw a scorn upon me, but she must revile me too? Fool, in scorn thou called'st me Mother, and thou shalt find the Malice of an old Woman here, that in her years, not desires, is aged; one that has lost that Mercy-kindling fire which should plead for thee, and prevent that youthful Malice, whose fruitful mischiefs shall make thee old in miseries; nor shall Religion, nor beauties of thy youth, protect thee from that dangerous hate thy scornes have bred, till thy despaires have taught thee how killing a Malice hot Lust in cold Limbs pursues.— The plot is here; Jealousie, 'tis thou must work my ends, with that I'le assault the Prince, and from the wounds it brings, reap my Revenge; for Jealousie, though it leave no scars behind, yet with desperate wounds it assailes the Mind.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p:
THis, by the description of the house, should be the place that holds my miseries: from what a second height of happiness am I fallen? Virgilius is young, and I fear, the guilt of having so many wayes ruin'd me will make him hate me for being innocent; But I am resolv'd, and will rather fall by misfortunes then faults; and, for the excellent Sophia's sake, will serve him till he blush to command me. And when his passion is over, he shall confess, I can bear a loss better then he rule a victory. But what are Enter Bragadine, Cicilia, and others. these? I must stand close. 'Tis he, and that (by her habit) the slave our Fortunes bow to: Gods! was it not enough we fell a sacrifice to the Julian Deity, and fill'd the Triumph of that Monarchy, that thus your rage pursues us? must all our Fortunes be slav'd to a slave, and bound with chaines to chaines.— Ye Gods! What
They pass by, Cicilia looks sadly on the ground, Facertes knows her.
She looks about upon Facertes all the way, till she goes off. Exeunt all but Facertes . do I see? Cicilia my Sister?

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: What said he?

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: It is she. Bless'd chance. Ye powers of Sicily, your hands are visible in this; forgive Facertes that confesses, Men may the metal bring, but the form of our happiness the Gods appoint us still.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. I.
div.stage: Enter the Captain, Lieutenant, Crabb, and Cilius.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: FAith, Sir, hanging of 'em will be but a hindrance to your self; 'tis true they are Rogues, and have no Conscience, yet, at the worst, they are so much horse.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I say, hang 'em.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: I say so to, if hanging were a punishment, but to them 'tis freedom.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No more dispute, but hang 'em slaves, to rob me now when I am quitting my Command.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Well, they shall be hang'd, but they shall stay till they be hungry, and have digested their full Cups; if if you hang 'em now they're full and drunk, they'le think they have but swallowed awry or surfeited; and instead of being punished, the Rogues will go out like Senatours.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: The old Souldier confesses they were of Sicily, and of Quality, and now sent for a Present to the Emperour, and that was the Vice-Roy that was slain, he would have yielded good money.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And one of the slaves confess'd the Woman was of such a Beauty, and so ravishing, that they fought who should purchase her.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: There had been a fellow for your Bird at home, two such fleas would suck a Man to death.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Come, talk no more on't now, there's no remedy, Go prepare those others for the Mart, and see the slaves hang'd: What? how do they look? is't a handsome fraight?

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Yes faith, Sir, there will be a jolly number with the Boys; and I would advise you, Sir, not to shew the Women and the Boys together, for they'le spoil the sale of the Wenches.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why then we'll sell the Women first.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Who these Sicilians should be, troubles me; if we made haste we might hear some news of her at Naples, for there they were sold.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: To morrow we'll provide for the journey; Lieutenant, see every thing in readiness.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Something I'll do, to give one of them her Freedom, as sure as you count her, though you refuse to sell it me.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Is the old fellow dead?

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: No. But I have prevail'd with him to quit his Physick; and I am certain, he hath neither eat, nor drank, nor slept since.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Let's go see him.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Cilius is melancholly for the Wench.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No matter, I'de rather he were angry then lost; for though he know not his own value, I know it, Come let's leave him.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: 'Tis not Treachery to save the Innocent. I'le do it.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I'Le sacrifice to Fortune, she shall henceforth be the Power I'le worship, to whom I owe this unexpected Joy, she ha's tam'd Lust, till it was Love, and lent onely so much sin to the wicked as served me; and I that could not stand safe among the Innocent, find a security among the wicked.— Facertes?

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Look here, ere I speak my news, Doe's not Virgilius see a Joy break like a Glory round about my Brow, to distinguish this my first happy hour?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: It is thy Friendship that sympathizes mine. Oh Facertes, such an accident hath hapned since thou left'st me, that I must wink, rub mine eyes, and call all my Reason to secure me I do not dream.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: What e're your Joyes are, they must give place to mine; for they are yours and mine, not as we are barely friends, but from the assurance that we shall ever be so.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I confess thy Joyes bring to me a greater Comfort then mine own, prithee give them a Name.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Do you believe a second view of her you have seen will not render her common to your eye? or, to possess those Beauties make them cheap in your Opinion? if not, I am happier then you, and when ever you enjoy your wishes I reap mine.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: By our Friendship I beg this blessing from you, yet this is not strange where Friendship is not strange.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: The slave is my Sister but by what accident fallen to this misery I know not.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Who? the fam'd Cicilia?

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: She. Never free till now, and this fall was but to raise her to a greater height.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Then I mistrust my Joyes; they grow too near a height to continue.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Are you sorry, Sir, it is she? Then it was not Chance changed our first design; is she less worthy of your Love now then before? I should be sorry to find your ignorance of what you valued preferred before your knowledge; or is there some second face you have met hath blotted out this too?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: O Facertes, why art thou so subject to mistake thy Friend?

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: If I mistake, why are you so sad? I found you full of joy.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Not that 'tis she makes me sad; for, witness Heaven, I have no wish beyond her,; Her Eye circles my Heaven, and till I have place in her esteem I am in Hell.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Why should that suspition make you sad, considering you are, and what you have done for her? Besides, am not I here with a Brother and a Friends interest?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Who I am, That, Facertes, begets my despairs; for that 'tis I is all Arguments against me; will she not, when she sees me, call to mind a Father (whose piety the Gods spared) fallen, to satisfie the lust of Empire? are not yet the wounds bleeding, and the yoke still laid upon her suffering Country? Now judge what can be said of hope, when this pleads against me. Oh Facertes, thou hast not read thy Sister, thou look'st with a Brothers eye, This fate I prophesie from one sight; and let me tell thee, if she be worthy of Virgilius she must hate Virgilius.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Sir, I confess my friendship made me oversee what I was reconcil'd to, and now I begin to fear; yet when she shall know how I have been obliged, That mercy I found from the fair Sophia, her honour will guide her to return Virgilius; for though it makes her to resent your injuries, yet she must be just to her, and then her gratitude secures you; for though she has honour, yet she has woman too, and mercy is as great an attribute as justice, and she cannot be always angry.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Against any thing but her frown I could arm, and this night be happy. For by a strange chance I have found a way (if she consent) to release her.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: By what accident came you to that power? have you seen her since?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: No, but this place is too publick; let's retire, and you shall know all; and when I would my Sister know, I'll read her through thy observations; but here let thy interest give way to my love.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: I shall obey, Sir.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. III.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: MY thoughts can find no rest; Love, wilt thou not quit me in Prison? art thou covetous of my chains too? Fool! hast thou not miseries enough of thine own? And yet I ought not to revile him; for he that hath fill'd my heart is full of honour, and could he guess my fate, I know he would quit a Crown, as a burthen, and seek a freedom in these chains. The Gods are just, to let me fall into these miseries, that we may taste what 'tis our ambition imposes upon others, guilty only as I was, by being too weak.— Whos's that? come in; Prisoners keep One knocks .no doors.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Madam, I come to tell you, our Captain has refused to sell me your freedom, and to morrow is the Mart at Naples; But if you dare trust him, whose misfortunes have made him appear your enemy, I'll gage a life to save your honour, and give you freedom. The plot is already laid, and those that were taken with you I have already acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Sir, I shall willingly obey any directions, without a thought of fear, for sure there's no condition below this.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: I will not now dispute this misfortune, but remedy it if I can; know, to morrow (lest the accident surprize you ere we put to sea) I have so ordered, that all the slaves that row in the Galley shall be loose, the Captain is my creature, and my self will still wait upon you, and be your guard; but be pleased to sit still when the word is given, and let us work your fate; But once free, command Cilius where you please, your friends too shall privately be arm'd.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Sir, what to say in return of this, I know not, and if you that can be thus gallant, thus good, cannot likewise from that honour that directs you now, find a reward, I fear you will lose this good deed.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: It is a debt all honest men owe your virtue; and I but obey my genius, for I know not what it is, but something whispers to my soul, and bids me serve you, and when my life can purchase you a good, you shall not need command it; I beseech you no reply, a Souldiers prayers (that seldom importunes heaven) I hope will protect you.—

div.stage: [Enter Lieu. and meets them as they are going out.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: How now, what's the news?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: I should speak with you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Madam, I'll wait upon you straight.— Are they all ready?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: I have done it, they are all resolv'd, I gave them their lives for it; and let him swear when he sees them there, 'tis no matter: they are all loose and arm'd, their chains are but for shew.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: No matter for his rage, let him storm; once aboard, we are masters, for he's but one, and what's a General without obedience? his power we give, and if a multitude knew their own strength, who can command that beast?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: I'll away, and send the other Galleys off before, lest they assist him.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Be faithful, and I'll make thee fortunate.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Sir, never fear it, I have said it, and I'll do it; he that refuses to be a knave for a handsome woman, may he dye honest, and be executed for a knave.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Where's the Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Here, Sir, I have waited this hour for you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Come, shall we go see the sick man?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: I'll follow you, Sir.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. IV.
div.stage: Enter Tullius, sick in his Bed, a Souldier with him, and Drums beating.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: NO rest! no ease! O miserable, miserable riches! some drink, O, some drink, ere this thirsty flame hath licked up all my life, meat, any thing to satisfie this wolf here.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: Have patience, it cannot last above a day or two, about which time I hope to see you quit of all the troubles of this world.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Let me sleep then, quiet those Drums, that I may dream of meat and drink; is there nothing to eat, no drink? oh misery of miseries!— Who's there? One knocks.

sp.speaker: Sould.
